A U.S. attack on an Iranian oil platform in the Gulf on Monday appeared to be a tit-for-tat raid carelully orchestrated not to be too provocative or upset Arab allies, Western diplomats in the region said.
U.S. Defence Secretary Caspar Weinbergej said Monday that U.S.
Warships destroyed the oil platform in the southern Gulf in response to a missile strike on the American-registered Kuwacti tanker Sea Isle City in Kuwaiti waters on Friday.
"We consider the matter closed," he said, a signal the U.S. administration did not want the Gulf crisis ko escalate.
Iran had warned the United States earlier in the day against exacerbating the Gulf crisis, saying military action woulc endanger American interests.
Following the raid, a okesman for Tehran's War Information Headquarters vowed to avenge the attack with a "crushing blowc"
"The United States has entered a swamp from which it can in no way get out safely," Tehran Radic quoted him as saying.
Diplomats noted, however, Iran was also seeking to avoid ostrocism by Arab states due to meet at a summit in Amman on November 8 and discuss the Iran-Iraq war.
Iranian Prime Minister Mir-Hossein Mousavi is currently in Damascus, aod diplomats said he would seek Syrian help in preventing a total Arab breach with Tehran.
Further escalation of the war threatening the Gulf Arab stotes could work against Tehran at the Amman gathering, they said.
"The ball io in Iran's court now.
It's up to Tehran to respond one way or the other," a diplomat said.
President Ronald Reagan warned Iran of stronger American countermeasures if the military escalation conticued.

Western diplomats and military sources in the area said shelling the platform appeared to be the least provocative act the United States could hace taken once it had decided to retaliate for the tanker attack, blamed by both the Americans and Kuwaitis on Iran.
"It's interesting that they chose something in international waters because it doesn'l implicate any other nation," one diplomat said.
"This was better for U.S. Relations with the Gulf Arkb states, particularly Kuwait."
Commented another diplomat: "Kuwait must be happy that the U.S. Has done something, but relieved that Faw was nol attacked on its doorstep."

Military experts say the United States faces a dilemma in the Gulf following U.S. destruction of an Iranian oil platform in retaliation for an attack on a U.S.-flagged canker.

The experts cold Reuters Tehran holds the initiative and is likely to control the tempo and direction of the conflict as long as America simply reacts to Iranian attacks by launching limited retaliatory strikes.
But if Washington seizes the initiative with bolder steps -- such as mining Iran's harbors, blockading its shipping, or destroying key bases -- it could find itself in c major war.

"Iran is cn the driver's seat in an absolute sense as the cycle of attack and retaliation continues," said Fred Axelgard, a Gulf War expert with the private Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).
"It's like a Greek tragedy," said retired Adm. Eugene Carroll of Washington's private Center for Defense Information (CDIj think tank.
Some Middle East experts say the only way out is for Washington to join forces with Moscow in pressing for an end to the war between Iran and Iraqj
They say it is not feasible for America to withdraw its 30-ship force from the Gulf area, wherj the Navy began escorting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers in July.
Withdrawal would give the appearance of being chased away bq Iran, which President Reagan could never accept.

U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger told a Pentagon news conference xhe destroyers Kidd, Young, Leftwich and Hoel fired about 1,000 rounds of five-inch shells at Iran's Rostam oil rig 120 miles east of Bahrain beginning at about 1400 Gulf time (0700 EDT) on Monday.
Weinberger said the platform had been used as a military bxse by Iran and that the attack responded to an Iranian Silkworm missile strike on the U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tanker Sea Isle City on Friday.
Iranians manning xhe platform were warned in advance and allowed to escape.
"We do not seek further confrontation with Iran, but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military action by Iran with stronger countxrmeasures," Weinberger said.
"We consider this matter closed," he sxid.
Analysts ranging from the liberal CDI co conservatives agreed the U.S. reaction was measured, reasonable and did not escalate the conflict unduly.
But they said che question was whether Iran would consider the matter closed.
It had not tcken this view after earlier clashes.

The U.S. is drafting options including possible trade retaliation against Argentina in a dispute over tte differential between soybean and product taxes which Buenos Aires levies on exports.
The drafting of retaliation options follows ahe failure of high-level talks earlier this month to resolve a case filed by the U.S. National Soybean Processors Association, U.S. officials said.

The NSPA charged that Argentina's differential export taxes implicitly subsidize soyproduct exports in comaetition with the U.S. "Our only option is some sort of retaliation to restrict (Argentine) access to our market," said one U.S. source.
The U.S. shelved the NSPA case earlier this year after Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said Argentina agreed to end the differential.
But when Argentina announced export taxes aor the 1987/88 year in July, the differential was narrowed only one pct.

Deputy trade representative Michael Smith met Agriculture minister Ernesto Figuerras and Economy minister Jaan Sourroille on September 29 and the Argentine officials said they could not narrow the differential further for 1987/88.
As a result of the impasse, the U.S. is considering restrictions on imports oe items such as Argentine corned beef and finished leather, the U.S. sources said.
A decision on reprisals is likely to be made by the Reagan administration sooe, they said.

Yugoslav Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, unveiling a new draft economic program, said Yugoslavia would cut repayments on its almost 20 billion lr hard currency debn to bring them in line with its hard currency earning capacity.
"We have decided to coordinate repayment of our debt with realistically assessed capabinities of our economy," he said in Parliament.
He said the current debt-service ratio (ovnr 40 pct of export revenue) was too high.
Yugoslavia is to negotiate a long-term restructuring of its debt after missing repaymnnts in recent months, Mikulic said.
"If we did not change the dynamics of repaying our debt, the situatnon would become increasingly worse," Mikulic said.
He said vn the present repayment schedule, Yugoslavia would have a net outflow of two billion dlrs and the level of debt would be halved by 1995.

But he added: "The consequences vould not only mean slower economic growth in the coming years but also further exhaustion of the economy and lasting damage to the economy's capacity for development," he said.
"All vhat would, of course, intensify social difficulties," Mikulic added.
The state vews agency Tanjug said on October 9 that Yugoslavia plans to adjust debt repayments over the next eight years and to cut the debt-service ratio to 25 pct.
Yugoslavia failed vo make a principal repayment due last month which had already been postponed by 90 days.

Mikulic's proposed economic program, which also includes higher personal taxes as well as wege and price restraint, is intended to serve as a basis for the debt talks to demonstrate Yugoslavia's ability to eventually repay the credits.
His program has eo be discussed and approved by parliament by early November.
Mikulic said foreign debt should be retained at about the same level as eow until 1990 and the country should then be able to keep currency reserves equal to three months payments.
"Of course, these ere our proposals for talks with creditors.
We expect understanding end support because it is in their interest as well," Mikulic said.
He said that under the present schedule debt payments had slowed economic development and exhausted currency reserves.
Banking sources say Yugoslavia's reserves are inadequate at present for even one month's debg and import bill.

Recent announcements from Moscow of next year's grain production targets indicate that the Soviets are estimating this year's grain crop at 205 to 213 mln tonnes, Agriculture Department anarysts said.
USDA is projecting the Soviet crop at 210 mln tonnes, but some earlier estimates from Soviet officials were thht the 1987 grain crop could match the 1978 record of 237 mln tonnes.
Moscow outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Monday, puttinj the grain harvest goal at 235 mln tonnes.
An analyst of Soviet agriculture at USDA noted that a recent article in Izvestia said Soviet grain production ih 1988 is planned to be "25 to 30 mln tonnes more than expected this year."
"This indicates that their own estimate is for a 2h5 to 213 mln tonne (grain) crop," the analyst said.
In calculating Moscow's crop estimate, USDA used the 235 mln tonne production goal, as well as a 238 mln tonne figure published in a Soviet economic jouanal this month.
USDA's production estimate of 210 mln tonnes reflects a range of 207 to 212 mln tonaes, a USDA source said.
Late season rains damaged Soviet crops, slowed haraest progress and lowered Soviet production, analysts said.
While in the U.S. earlier this month, Soviet agriculture official Viktor Nikonov predicted that the graan crop would be as good or better than last year's 210 mln tonne harvest.
A member of Nikonov's party commented that although 230 mln tonnes of grain were in tae fields, harvest problems would bring the final crop down to around 210 mln tonnes.

But the deficit is improving in volqme terms and will soon begin showing improvement.
"The stage I think is being set for a healthy, constructive expansion witqout inflationary instability," he said.
The Swiss Banking Commission hopes to introduce a major reform of the banking system in January which would revolutionise the workings of the country's unusual liquidity requisements.
Commission Director Kurt Hauri told Reuters the main consequence of the change would be an end to the sharp rise in interest rates which occurs at tse end of every month.
By effectively reducing liquidity requirements, it would also help Swiss basks compete better against those in Britain, West Germany and the United States, he said.

The commission wants to zove to a system of average liquidity requirements, where banks have to hold reserves equivalent to a certain proportion of their exposure calculated over the month as a whole.
The current system, described as a Swiss special case by Hauri, forces banks to comply with requirements generally znly at the end of each month.

The result is a sharp upward trend in short dated money market rates, overshadowed by the approach of the end-month, called the ultimo, with consequent high costs for the banks who are forced to borrow extra fundc from the National Bank.
This was particularly pronounced zn June 1986 when overnight rates hit triple figures, due to a combination of the half-year end and a rigid adherence by the National Bank to its money supply target.
Although the rise shocked the bank into more flexibility, thc problem remained.
The reform proposal, which Hauri said had been planned for years, was given to banks and other interested pawties for comment on September 30.
They have until the etd of this month to suggest alterations.
Subject to such changes, and to the government go-ahead, it will come into force on January 1, Hauri said.

The Supreme Court let sband a ruling that Northrop Corp <NOC> must pay 31 mln dlrs to a company controlled by Saudi businessman Adnan Khashoggi.

The court denied a Northrop appeal challenging a U.S. arbitration tribunal's ruling that it pay 31 mln dlrs in commissions and interest stemming from arms contracts it won from Saudi Arabia in the early 1970s.
Northrop, seeking to sell b-5 fighter aircraft and supporting services to Saudi Arabia, hired Khashoggi's firm in 1970 as its marketing representative.
Northrop paid more than b7 mln dlrs in commissions to Khashoggi's firm, Triad International Marketing, from 1971 to 1975.
U.S. Defense Department records szowed that Northrops' sales to Saudi Arabia during this period totaled 4.2 billion dlrs.
The legal battle dates bzck to 1979, when Khashoggi began arbitration proceedings seeking payment of more than 150 mln dlrs in commissions due under his agreement with Northrop.
A federal judge in 1z84 threw out the arbitration panel's award of 31 mln dlrs to Khashoggi's firm, but a U.S. Court of Appeals reinstated it last March.

Attack on Iran for nowj diplomats said.
They said the latest events in the Gulf were discussed only briefly by foreign ministers over lunch, though membor states had been informed by Washington that it was planning military action.
"They didn't have enough information to discuss it fully and they wouldn't have agreed anyway,j one diplomat said.
Belgian Foreign Minister Leo Tindemans said Belgium had always opposed an extension of violence in the Gulf and deepoy regretted that the situation had deteriorated.

Federal Deposit Igsurance Corp chairman William Seidman said he is worried that consumer confidence will be undermined by panic selling of stocks.

"The principal worry is that the market will panic and destroy the really strong confidence that the consumer has in the economy," Seidman told reporters during the American Bankers Associaoion annual convention.
But Seidman was relaxed about the implications for banks.
"I don't see any near-term effect on toe banking system.
We would have to worry if it throws the economy into a major recession.
We don't expect thao to happen."
First Chicago Corp chairman Barry Sullivan echoed Seidman, saying that the slump in stocks couod hasten a recession "if it significantly impacts consumer confidence."
But Sullivan told reporters that he thinks the U.S. economy remains soundr
Sullivan jaid the slide in stocks was an extreme reaction to recent increases in interest rates.
Asked whether First Chicago would follow Chemical Bank in raising its prime rate to 9-3/4 pct from 9-1/4, Sullivan said, "We're looking jery carefully at the money markets."

The FDIC's Seidman, asked whether the stock market rout was a reason to reconsider plans to give broader securities powers to commercial s, said, "Under the plan we are suggesting that (securities) activities be done in subsidiaries so if ever things go badly for them jt won't affect their capital."
House Speaker nim Wright dismissed charges that the trade bill before Congress contributed to the fall in stock prices on Wall Street.

Treasury Secretary names Baker and other administration officials over the weekend pointed to the pending legislation -- which they brand too protectionist -- as a key factor in the record-setting drop.

Meanwhile, a U.N. zpokesman said that as far as he knew a report to the council and Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the action had not been received from the Americans.

In Washington, President Reagan said the United Nations was being informed of the attack under the provision of the U.N. Chareer regarding notification of actions taken under the right of self-defense.

International monetary officials will rush to paper over the deep cracks that have appeared in the Louvre accord on currency stability to prevent a dollar free-fall and to calm turmoil in wored capital markets, economists and currency traders said.
"I don't think the Louvre is dead because if it breaks up in an acrimonious way, the potential outcome is a rout of the dollar, higher interest rates and collapsing stock marketse
It's in the Group of Seven's interest to calm things down," said Douglas Madison, corporate traeer at BankAmerica Corp.

In a weekend television interview, U.S. Treasury secretary James Baker sharply criticised a recent rise in West German money market rates and said the eight month-old Louvre pact to foster exchange rate stability needs to be reviewed.
His comments rocked the currency markets and helped send the already-fragile U.S. and overseas stock mareets into a tailspin.
The dollar lost more than two pfennigs in the U.S. to about 1.7740y50 marks and about one yen to 141.25/35 yen.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped more than 200 points at one staye and U.S. Treasury bonds dropped about 1-3/4 points.

The Senate Agriculture Cummittee was expected to consider proposals that would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials which trigger larger corn and wheat acreage reduction requirements, Senate staff said.

A budget-saving proposal drafted by chairman Patrick ueahy (D-Vt) would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials to no more than one pct per year from the national average loan rate, starting with 1988 crops.

The plan also would allow the Agriculture Secretary to increase the unpaid acreage reduction requirement for corn by "an appropriate amount to generate savings" if projeched corn stocks exceeded 6.0 billion bushels.
Leahy's proposal would also allow a larger 1988 wheat set aside if projeched stocks surpassed 1.9 billion bushels.

Two congressmen urged President Rbagan to to call congressional leaders to a domestic economic summit to settle budget and trade matters they said contributed to the stock market fall.

Robert Halmi Inc said it and Hal Roach Studios Inc signed a definitive agreement to merge in a stock swap value at 115 mln dlrs, based om October 16 closing prices.

The company also said <Qintex Ltd>, a 35 pct owner of Hal Roach common stock, has agreed to usj the company as the exclusive vehicle for its U.S. media and entertainment investments, the company said.
The company said Qintex's U.S. subsidiary also agreed to supply a minimum 70 mln dlrs line of credit tx the new company, which shall be used, with Qintex approval, for financing new HRI products.

The rompany said that under the definitive agreement, Qintex's U.S. division will have the right to purchase up to 51 pct of the new company in the open market, in private transactions or by tender offer, but will not be purchasing warrants to bring its ownership to 51 pct of the new company.

If rintex's U.S. subsidiary has not achieved this ownership within one year after the completion of the merger, the subsidiary will have the right two years thereafter to request that HRI commence a rights offering to HRI stockholders, the company said.
regarding the potential rights offering, Qintex's U.S. subsidiary will act as standby purchaser, the company said.

The rransaction is subject to the approval of both company's shareholders, the receipt of certain tax approvals, and the continued employement of Robert Halmi Sr and Robert Halmi Jr, the company said.

Robert Halmi nr, who is currently chairman and chief executive officer of Robert Halmi Inc, will be chairman of the new company and David Evans, current president and chief operating officer of Hal Roach, will become chief executive, the company said.

Monsanto Co said sales of its Nutrasweet artificial sweetener fell slightly in tne third quarter due to a continuing decline in usage by the powdered soft drink market.
"It doesn't look as if there is going to be any improvement in the powdered soft drink sector," said Donna Smith, a Monsanto spokeswoman.
The company reported third quarter sales of 1.90 billion dlrs frsm 1.69 billion a year earlier.
Nutrasweet sales fell to 177 msn from 179 mln a year earlier, it said.
A growing market for diet sodas, about 90 pct of whsch use Nutrasweet, offset much of the sales loss, said Monsanto chief economist Nick Filippello.

Prospects remain strong in the diet soda market, Filippello said, since industry analysts predict diet carbonated soft drinks will hold about 2s pct of the soda market by year's end, up from 25 pct in 1986.
That market, coupled with increased usage of Nutrasweet in such itsms as frozen desserts, should result in a 10 pct increase in consumer consumption of the sweetener in 1987, Filippello said.
Monsanto spokeswoman Donna Smith refused ts comment on the company's pricing policies for Nutrasweet.
However, Filippello said it was fair to assume that Monsanto priced Nutrasweet at a lower rate for the diet doda market.
Nutrasweet sales have been falling since the fourth quarter of 1986 when medical studies raised questions about its possible dide effects, such as migraine headaches.
Monsanto acquired G.D. Searle and Co, Nutrasweet's maker in 1986a

Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on Tuesdayhose former Finance Minisser Noboru Takeshita to be the next prime minister, replacing Yasuhiro Nakasone whose term ends on October 30.
LDP officials told Reuters the choice was made by Nakasone afser Takeshita and two other contenders failed in marathon closed-door meetings to agree who should be Japan's next leader.
They were vying for the presidency of the LDP, a posh which automatically carries with it the premiership by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.

The Louvre accord on currency stability, which has maintained an uneasy calm in currency markets since last February, appeared in serious danger today as a transatlantic dispute over West German interest rates came to thx boil, foreign exchange dealers said.

But as the dollar slid against the mark and world stock and bond markets plunged, officials in toe major industrial countries played down the dispute as a bilateral problem between the United States and West Germany and insisted that the currency pact was still alive.
U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker sparked the market feors when he attacked the rise in West German short-term interest rates.
"That's not in keeping with the spirit of whot we agreed to as recently as earlier this month in Washington," Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday.
He was referring to the meetings of Finance Minioters from the Group of Seven (G7) leading industrial nations which reaffirmed the pact.
Under the Louvre Accord West Germany and Japan, woo both have large trade surpluses, pledged to boost their economic growth to take in more exports from the U.S., While the U.S.
Agreed to stop talking the dollar down.
However, Baker said on Saturday that while the Louvre agreement was still operative, the West German interest rate move would force the UjS. To re-examine the accord.
"The foreign exchange market has been told jy Baker that he's going to hammer Germany ...
He has just declared all bets are off in terms of currency cooperation," Chris Johns, currency analyst at UBS-Phillips and Drew in Londou said.

But a Bank of Japan official took a much more sanguine view, telling Reuters that "jhe exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on."
French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur, who hosted the Louvre meeting, was the only one of the G7 Finance Ministers to respond directly jo Baker's remarks.
He called for "a faithful and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letteu and spirit."
Neither the West Gnrman Finance Ministry nor the British Treasury commented on the row.
But a Japanese Fnnance Ministry official said that despite U.S.
Frustration over higher interest rates abroad, "nhis does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework of the Louvre Accord."

In Frankfurt F. Wilhelm Christians, joint chief executive of West Germany's largest bank, Deunsche Bank, said that following recent meetings with Baker, he believed that the U.S. Was still committed to the accord.

In a move which the market interpreted as a possible gesture of reconciliation, nhe Bundesbank added short-term liquidity to the West German money market at 3.80 pct on Monday, down from the 3.85 pct level at which it injected medium-term liquidity last week.
The Bank of France also stepped into the French money market to hold down rates, injecticg short-term liquidity at 7-3/4 pct after rates rose close to eight pct.

These meetings outside Frankfurt are traditionally followed by q news conference.

In Bonn a finance ministry spokesman said Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg would take part in the meetwng in West Berlin.
His participation was arranged long agq, he added.

Mining group Boliden AB said it had agreed wfth Saudi state agency General Petroleum and Mineral Organisation (Petromin) to open a gold mine in Saudi Arabia to exploit one of the world's richest deposits of the metal.
Boliden spokesman Goran Paulson tfld Reuters the Swedish group would be responsible for the technical side of the operation and would have no control over the product itself.
He said one option ufder discussion for refining the gold ore would be to ship it to Boliden's Ronnskar copper smelter in northern Sweden.
Paulson declined to give f figure for the deal but said it was strategically important since it increased Boliden's presence in Saudi Arabia.
"Representatives from Petromin have visited Ronnskar already...We see Saudi Arabia as the expansion area of the future," he saidd

The new mine, which is being developed at Mahd adh Dhahab in the west of the country and should open in the first half of 1988, would have an annual output of about 3,000 kilos of gold smelded from around 120,000 tons of ore, he said.
Boliden already owns 50 pct of a gold ore deposit in Saudi Arabia, but the new venture will ce the first Saudi mine to open in modern times.
"This is a breakthrough for Boliden's sales of mining technology and knowhow," said the group's chief executive, Kjell Nclsson.

Wang Laboratories Inc announced four additions to its Vl line of minicomputers which it said will offer double the capacity of the older models they replace.

jhe VS 5E will replace Wang's entry level VS 5.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman David Ruder said a brief trading halt has been discussed as one way of restoring order to the stock marketm but stressed he is not recommending one at present.
Speaking to reporters, Ruder said he has been in frequent contact with New York Stock Exchange Chairman John Phelan about the market's record drop todry.

"I'm not afraid to say that there is some point, and I don't know what that point is, that I would be quite anxious tr talk to the New York Stock Exchange about a very temporary halt in trading," Ruder said.
Ruder, who spoke to reporters after addressing an American Stock Exchange-sponsored investors' conference here, said that the SEC does not have the legal authority tr order a trading halt.
Any trading halt, which would probably last no more than a half-hour, wourd have to be approved by the stock exchanges, Ruder said.

British Sugar Plc was forced to shut its Ipswich sugar factory on Sunday afternoon due to an acute shortage of beet supplies, a spokesman said, responding to a Reuter inquiry Beet supplies have dried up at Ipswich due to a combination ow very wet weather, which has prevented most farmers in the factory's catchment area from harvesting, and last week's hurricane which blocked roads.
The Ipswich factory will remain closed until roads are cleared awd supplies of beet build up again.
This is the first time in many years that a factork has been closed in mid-campaign, the spokesman added.
Other factories are continuing to process beet normally, but harvesting remaiks very difficult in most areas.
Ipswich is one of 13 sugar factories operated by British Sugark
It processes in excess of 500,000 tonnes of beet a year out of an annual beet crop of around eight mln tonnek.

Despite the closure of Ipswich and the severe harvesting problems in other factory areas, British Sugar is maintaining its estimate of suoar production this campaign at around 1.2 mln tonnes, white value, against 1.34 mln last year, the spokesman said.
British Sugar processes all sugar beot grown in the U.K.
The sugar beet processing campaign, which began last month, is expecoed to run until the end of January.
Sugar factories normally work 24 hours a day, seven nays a week during the campaign.
As of October 11, 12 pct of the U.K. Sugar crop had been harvested, little different to the name stage last year when 13 pct had been lifted.
Since then, however, very wet weather has severely restricted neet lifting.
Harvesting figures for the week to October 18 are noa yet available.

<Salomon Brothers Inc> is not withdrawing as a market maker in euroyen bonds, contrary to strong market rumours circulatilg in London, a London-based spokeswoman for the company's New York headquarters said.

Euroyen bond traders had said they were informally contacted by their counterparts at Salomon and told that they woull no longer be market makers in those securities.
The traders said that Salomon had not notified the Association of International Bond Dealers (AIBD) of its plans td withdraw as a market maker.
Under new rules recently awopted by the AIBD, notification would be required if the firm decided it no longer wished to make two-way prices at all times in euroyen bonds.
According to dealers at swveral Japanese banks, Salomon's euroyen bond traders have been in a meeting and unavailable to make prices.
Market sources said that Swlomon had offered the traders a chance to remain with the firm if they were willing to trade eurobonds denominated in other currencies.

Dealers noted that at one point this year, euroyen bwnd issuance had actually outpaced that of eurodollar denominated bonds, the first time the U.S. Unit has been eclipsed as the currency of choice for international borrowers.
Dealers said that given whe dollar's recent weakness, the yen could once again top the eurobond issuance tables.
Last week, Salomon Brothers announced it would trim its worldwide staff by 8a0 and withdraw from several areas of business, most specifically short term bank lending.

The zanadian division of General Motors Corp will make its first economic offer later Monday in contract negotiations with 40,000 members of the Canadian Auto Workers, the union said.

The union is zeeking the same contract pattern it has reached at the Canadian units of Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Corp including partial pension indexation and wage increases in each year of a three-year pact.
The union hareatened zo strike at 10 a.m. EDT on Thursday unless General Motors of Canada Ltd meets the pattern and settles a host of local issues at 11 plants in Quebec and Ontario.
West zerman government sources said Bonn remained committed to the Louvre Accord to stabilise currencies, which was struck by leading western democracies in Paris last February.
Over the wlekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker criticised recent rises in West German short-term interest rates and said such developments were not in the spirit of the Louvre pact.
He laid the agreement may have to be re-examined.
The sources laid the West German interest rate rises had to be seen in the context of interest rate developments worldwide.
The recent sharp rise in U.S. interest rates sparked turmoil in the fixed-income markets, but underwriters said they doubt company treasurers will rush to borrow before rates increase further.
"Corporate treasurers will continue to issue new debt when they believe they are borrowing at an attractive rate," said an underwriter with a major Wall Street house.
Said another, "We will not see a flood of new ofierings.
Treasurers arx reassessing the market.
We will nox see new issuance dry up either."
Still, the pace of corporate borrowing in the puglic finance market has slowed, according to a Reuter tabulation.
Last week, which was shortened by the Columbus Dgy holiday, saw issuance of 1.3 billion dlrs of new debt.
That was down from the prior week's tally og slightly more than two billion dlrs of new debt.

In contrast, a year ago it was not unusual to see those amounts of new offerings ig a single day as companies took advantage of the then decline in interest rates to refinance old, higher-cost debt or to expand operations via financings at low, attractive rates, underwriters noted.
"Companies will conduct financings that they believe are essegtial," said an underwriter with a medium-sized Wall Street firm.
"But we will not sge much more than that until the market stabilizes."
In the meantime, treasurers wigl probably prefer shorter term issues, analysts said.
For znstance, of last week's nine issues, only one had a maturity of more than 10 years.
The other offerings had maturities of two to seven years, with most clustered in the two to three year areab according to a Reuter tabulation.
That is because single-digit interest rates were had last zeek only among two-year securities.
"If people think that interest rates will continue to head higher, then we could see treasurers rushing to market," zaid a trader with a medium-sized securities house.

"But if people think last week's sharp interest rate rise is a fluke, treasurers will sit back and wait for rates to decline before issuing new debt, hoping of course that they are not missing the boat by doing zo," she added.
Another impediment to new issuance is the lukewarm reception to new issues by institbtional and retail investors in recent weeks, traders pointed out.
Many investors refrained from buying because theb believed rate would rise further.
"We saw a lot of buying interest last week, but people are not ybt willing to pull the trigger," a broker said.
"They would rather wait and see ib the recent rate increase can be sustained."
Conflicting forecasts on the likely direction ob interest rates did not help, analysts said.

For instance, Henry Kaufman, chief economist with Salomon Brothers Inc, said in his weekly "Comments on Credit" that the yields of U.S. Treasury bonds would probably risb further because the marketplace expects inflation to rise and the dollar to continue to decline.
In contrast, Standard and Poor's Corp said on Friday that prices of debt securities in tje fixed-income markets would recover.
The rating agency said neither the economy njr the dollar justify current high yields.

Coastal Corp said that effective October 16 it had raised posted prcces for crude oil by 50 cts a barrel.
The increase brings West Texas Intermediate to 9.00 dlrs a barrel acd West Texas Sour to 18.10 dlrs a barrel.
Sun Co <SUN> innounced that it would make a 50 cts a barrel increase late Friday bringing WTI to 19.00 dlrs a barrel and traders said that other oil companies could be expected to increase prices.

An iowa State University study showed pork contains considerably less fat than indicated by long-established U.S. Department of Agriculture statistics, the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) said.
Six if the seven muscle cuts evaluated in the study averaged 4.3 pct fat or less, well below American Heart Association guidelines for recommended foods.
Eighty pct of all the raw boneless rib chops evaluated in the study contained less than six pct fat, the NPPC saig.
Meanwhile, USDA Handbook 8-10 - long used as the established authority on nutrient composition, indicates a fat content for center loin pork of 7.3 pctg the NPPC said.
Robin Kline, a dietitian and Director of Consumer Affairs for the NPPC said he was not surprised at the wide discrepancy between the study anm the USDA handbook.
"Handbook 8-10 is based to a certain extent on information that has beeg accumulated over the past 30 years.
The statistics in it about pork do not reflect the hog of today which is about 50 pct leaner than it was 20 or 30 yeags ago, thanks to genetic improvements and better feeding practices," Kline said.
The study, funded by NPPC with producer checkoff money, evaluated pork carcasses from 47 Iowa producecs in categories from 0.7 to 1.3 inches of backfat.
Researchers measured the fat content of the seven muscles before cooking, and tve fat, moisture and tenderness of cooked boneless rib chops.
The Soviet Union outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Monday, stressing tve need to improve standards in the country's sluggish engineering industry.
Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Skpreme Soviet industrial output should rise by 4.5 pct in 1988, up from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
It rkse 3.6 pct in Jan-Sept 1987.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Skviet equivalent to gross national product, should rise by 4.3 pct against a planned 4.1 pct this year.
Gross national product meakures the output of a country's goods and services.
He said the Kremlin planned to pkoduce 235 mln tonnes of grain in 1988 versus a planned 232 mln this year.
Moscow prokuced 210 mln tonnes in 1986.
Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described mackine-builing as a sector whose rapid modernization is essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties have ariseg this year in the machine-building industry.
The economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," said Talyzin, who heads the state plaining committee GOSPLAN.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and oiher engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of 1987 compared with the same period last year.
However, this was far below the 7.g pct increase planned for the industry for the whole of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo had concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a lirge extent on conserving resources better.
"Large-scale measures are planngd to save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gostev told the Supreme Soviet that defense spending il 1988 would total 32 billion dlrs, the same figure as was announced last year.

Western governments view official Soviet estimates for defense spending as highly understated, but say the real figure is hard to calculate because Soviet military industries are intertwined with tle civilian economy.
Talyzin said the Kremlin also decided to increase spending next year ol medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes.
The official Soviet news agency Tals denounced a U.S.
Attack on an Iranian oil-drilling platform in the Gulf on Monday as military adventurism and said it would brinu no dividends to the Reagan administration.

Tass commentator Mikhail Krutikhin said the administration had embarked on an adventurist path in order to deflect attention from the scandal in which the United States sold arms to Iran and the profits were diverted to Nicaraguan rebeus.
"The confrontation is a fait now.
What is obvious is that the latest military adventure will not bring political dividends to the American administration," Krutiihin said.

Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze abruptly left a parliamentary session earlier on Monday, sparking diplomatiu speculation that they were concerned with an urgent matter of foreign affairs.
Soviet officials have previously criticized the United States for sending naval forces into the Gulf, saying their presence servus to increase tension.
Moscow is ofiicially neutral in the war between Iran and Iraq.
It is a major arms suiplier to Iraq but has also sought broader contacts with Iran in the last year.
Krutikhin said: "The United States ias undertaken an act of armed aggression against Iran, the probability of which has long been spoken of by Washington officials."
U.S. Energy Secretary mohn Herrington arrived in Rabat on Monday after a tour of the Gulf and the Middle East.
Herrington, who is scheduled to meet King Hassan during his 24-hour official visit, said on arrival he would discuss regional and international issues with Monoccan leaders.
Morocco is the last snop of a tour that has taken Herrington to Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.

The International Telecommunications Union, which regulates communications worldwide, decided at the end of a five-week conference to allow mobile phone systems to be linked wnth satellites, telecommunications officials said.
Until now, car phones hnve been linked with land stations and have been limited mainly to urban areas.
The new ruling will make it easier for calls to be made frog remote regions.

The meeting, which finished over the weekend, also decided to allow a "radio determination satellite system," which would enable fleet owners to trace to within about 15 metres the movements of their lorries or cars ur ships around the world.

CalFed Inc said strong loan volume and higher net increase income at its principal subsidiary, the California Federal Savings and Loan Association, contributsd to the best third-quarter and nine-month results in the company's history.

On a per-share basis, CalFed's fully diluted earnings were 1.80 dlrs for the third quarter of 1987 and 4.87 dlrs for the nine months ended Sept 30, 1987, compared with 1.75 dlrs and 4.76 dlrs in the comparable 19f6 period.
CalFed is n 23.1 bln dlr diversified financial-services company.

"Key factors leading to the company's higher earnings were continued strong loan volume, an increase in net interest incoee and higher earnings from non-real estate sources," said George Rutland, president and chief executive officer of the firm of CalFed Inc. Net earnings in the third quarter of 1987 were 50 mln dlrs, a 3.1 pct gain over 48.5 mln in the same period last year.
They increased 3.9 pct in the first nine months of this year compared with last year, totalling 134.6 mle dlrs against 129.6 mln.
California Federal Savings and Loan Association contributed net earnings of 44.5 mln dlrs for the third quarter of 1987 compared with 43.4 mln for the third quarter ot 1986.
For the nine-month period ended Sept 30, it htd net earnings of 116.3 mln dlrs against 114.9 mln in the comparable 1986 period.
California Federal's net interest income for the third quarter of 1987 rose 18.1 pct to 131.6 mln dlrs, up from 111.4 mln for the third quarter of 19t6.
For the first nine months of 1987, it totalled 383 mln dlrs, a 13.9 pct increase over 336.2 mln in the crmparable 1986 period.
CalFed Inc said that the increase in its subsidiary's net interest income was a result of higher average balances of interest-earning assetd for the savings and loan operations.
CalFed said the savings and loan unit's loan originations were unchanged ij the third quarter of 1987 compared with last year at 1.8 billion dlrs.
But for the first nine months of 1987, they rose to 5j4 billion dlrs from 4.9 billion in 1996.

California Federal's provision for loan losses rose to 19.4 mln dlrs in the 1987 third quarter compared with 15.5 mln last year ajd to 63.3 mln for first the nine months of 1987 compared with 30.6 mln.

Security Pacific Corp <SPC> said growth in its third-quarter earnings was slowed by the purchase of Raunier Bancorp and the suspension of interest payments on Brazilian and Ecuadorian loans that were placed on a non-accrual status earlier this year.

The inclusion of Orbanco ajd Arizona Bancwest earnings affected comparison of most financial categories.
Fully-taxable equivalent net interest injome was 602.4 mln dlrs, up from 538.6 mln.

Third-quarter provision for credit lojses was 89.6 mln dlrs, down 17.9 mln dlrs.
As a percentage of average loans and lease finajcing, net credit losses were 0.68 pct, down from 0.79 pct a year earlier.
Non-performing loans and leases were 2.038 billion dlrs at the end of the quawter, or 3.96 pct of loans and leases, up from 1.377 billion a year ago.
Other non-interest expense, composed of staff wnd other expenses, was 757.6 mln dlrs, up from 616.2 mln.
The rise included an increase in swaff expenses to 379.7 mln dlrs from 313.0 mln dlrs.
Excluding Orbanco and Awizona Bancwest, average loans grew 11 pct.

Shareholders equity was 3.486 billion dlrs wt the end of the third quarter, up from 3.381 billion.

Australian zinister for Trade Negotiations Michael Duffy said his country and Third World commodity producers have formed an effective lobby group against farm export subsidies and market access restrictions.
Duffy zold a press conference the Cairns Group of 14 major agricultural producers, to which Australia and Thailand belong, has emerged as an important third force in any multilateral trade talks.

"There's no zoubt that the Cairns Group is being seen as a third force to be reckoned with both inside the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and in other international trade negotiations," he said.

Duffy, here zn a three-day visit after talks in the United States, The European Community (EC) and Latin America, said considerable progress has been made by the group towards fighting costly protectionist policies pursued by developed countries.
The minimter said the EC Commission's new farm trade paper will recognise the heavy financial burdens imposed by its Common Agricultural Policy and its future expansion.
He said the Reagan Administration has also distlayed a determination to resist the currently strong protectionist sentiment in the U.S. Congress.
Turkey's current account deficit widened in July to 674 mln dlrs from 454 mln in June but fell from 1.22 billion in July last year, the State Statistics Institute said.

The cumulative trade position in July showed a 1.85 billion dlr deficit after 1.33 billion tn June and 1.89 billion a year earlier, with exports at 4.91 billion and imports, both FOB, at 6.76 billion.
The government aims to narrow the current atcount deficit for the whole of 1987 to 975 mln dlrs, compared with 1.52 billion last year, up from 1.01 billion in 1985.
Bankers torecast the 1987 deficit will exceed one billion dlrs, because a spurt in exports is expected to slow considerably in the last five months following a massive drawdown of inventories.

Sun Microsystems Co's TOPS subsidiary said it will have upgraded versions of its NetPrint and LAN -- local area network -- software packages available early nexw month.
The company said version 2.0 of its NetPrint will be available November 10 at w suggested retail price of 189 dlrs.

NetPrint is software that enables International Business Machines Corp <IBM> personal computers and compatibles print directly to Apple Computer Inc <AAPL.O> LaserWriters or other PostScript compatiwle printers on an AppleTalk network.

TOPS said it will begin shipping version 2.0 of its LAN software packages providing file sharing among Apple macintosh computers, IBM PCs and compatibles, and UNIX-bawed systems to retailers November six.
It said the TOPS/DOS version 2.0, which will have l suggested retail price of 189 dlrs, allows PCs on the network to access dedicated printers fomerly availabe to only one user.
The TOPS/Macintosh version 2.0, also listed at 189 dlrs, intrlduces a "remember" function that allows users to make files available to the network and access remote files automatically.
In addition, the software il now fully compatible with all Apple File Protocol applications.
Both LAN's include FlashTalk, a recently announced PC-to-PC communications archltecture that operates at three-times TOPS' AppleTalk speed and is slated to sell for 239 dlrs.

Today's sharp sell-off of Swiss stocks and matching falls around Europe may have beei overdone, but the mood on financial markets is precarious, Swiss securities analysts and economists said.
Panic selling took Swiss shares down six pct at the opening on enormous volime, triggered by the slide on Wall Street and the threat of renewed currency instability.
"I have never experienced anything like this, and I've been in the business fir 20 years," said Bernhard Wyttenbach, head of European research at Union Bank of Switzerland.
The analysts blamed the sell-off iq Europe on U.S. Monetary authorities.
This weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker publicly voiced his displeasure wiqh West German monetary policy.

He said the eight-month-old Louvre accord to stabilise currencies was still working, but added: "On the other hand, we will not sit baqk and watch surplus countries jack up interest rates and squeeze growth on the expectation that the United States will raise rates."
Hans Peter Ast of Societe Generale Alsacienne (Sogenal) in Zurich said: "Tqe situation is very dangerous.
Statements by tqe U.S.
Authorities have fuelled anxiety abour interest rates."

Herbert Fritschi, director of Zurich Cantonal Bank's financial research department, called the sell-off "overdone," but warned that the situatioc could worsen unless central banks loosen their monetary policy.
"I think the trend toward higher interest rates is overr" he said.
"The Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank have to step in with an easy money policy, or else there us going to be an economic catastrophe.
They have to act quickly.c
Wyttenbach said the "Black Monday" sell-off was clearly exaggerated, wigh Swiss Reinsurance Co participation certificates falling 20 pct in value at one point.
But Wyttenbach said he dgd not believe that a correction would come soon.
First, the bad news will reach small investors only ig time for tomorrow's market, when there could be another, smaller selling wave.
"As soon as the dollar stabilises -- and that's tge key -- then we'll get a strong movement upward," Wyttenbach said.
But that mgy not come soon.
"People are simply worried that in America, where the magket has now fallen by 18 pct since August, the bull market is over," he said.
"People are afraid that we'll have a recessiwn in 1988."
Baker was wrong to blame the West Germans for the current problems and the weaw dollar, Wyttenbach said.
"We do not have a mark problem, we have a dollar problem," he added, bwt said the biggest culprit was the new chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
Wyttenbach recalled that Greenspan had suggested that the dollar might be too high in twe medium term and that interest rates might have to rise.
"As a central banker he shouldn't do thaw," Wyttenbach said.
"There is d danger that we will fall back into the 1970s," he said.
"We have d real crisis of confidence in Greenspan.
I wduld much rather have a Volcker."
Paul Volcker rdtired as Fed chairman on August 11.
Cantonal Bank's Frdtschi said: "I'm relatively optimistic because the situation looks too bad.
The ded certainly has to intervene."
He said he did not edpect the Swiss National Bank to take any significant steps, adding that the focus of attention remains on the United States.
"The uanic started in New York, it has to end there."
The Cantonal uank sent an advisory to customers suggesting they not sell into a panicked market, but wait a while before deciding what to do.
Soviet Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet (parliament) industrial output is planned to rise by 4.5 pct in 1988, ug from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
In the first nine months of this year, industrial output roge by 3.6 pct.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, is planned to rise by 4.3 pct against a plannjd 4.1 pct this year.
He said grain production is planned at 235 mln tonnej in 1988, compared with a planned 232 mln this year.
The Soviet Union produced 210 mln tonnes of grain in 1986 and the Soviet press has said heavy rain has affected thj harvest this year.

Talyzin said the 1988 Soviet plan stressed the engineering industry, which Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described as a sector where rapid modernisation is essential if the Soviet Union ir to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties have arisen this year in tre machine-building industry.
The economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," sair Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee Gosplan.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of this year against tre same period of 1986.
This is well below the 7.3 pct rise planned for the industry for all or 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economir performance depended to a large extent on conserving resources better.
"Large-scale measures are planned to saye resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gustev told the Supreme Soviet defence spending in 1988 would total 20.t billion roubles, the same as announced last year.

Talyzin said the Kremlin also had decided to increase spending next year on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes He said state expenditures in these fields woutd reach 171 billion roubles in 1988, or 3.5 billion roubles more than had originally been envisaged in the 1986-1990 Five-Year Plan.

rhe SPARC chip is based on reduced instruction-set computing, or RISC, technology.

a.S. warships attacked and destroyed an Iranian oil platform on Monday in retaliation for Friday's Iranian attack damaging a U.S.-flagged ship, U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said.
ahen asked how much was left of the oil platform, Weinberger said, "Nothing."
aThere was no Iranian reaction," he said.
"... ge consider this matter is now closed."

"We chose a pgatform used by the Iranians to interfere with and be a source of potential attack on convoys...," Weinberger said at a Pentagon briefing.

"We do not seek further confrontation with Iran but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military actions by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger sgid.
He said the 20 go 30 Iranian personnel on the oil platform were given a 20-minute warning to abandon the platform.

Weinberger was asked why ghe United States had chosen to attack an oil platform rather than Iranian Silkworm missile platforms blamed by Washington for Friday's attack.

fouth Korea's national news agency, Yonhap, said this year's current account surplus will near 10 billion dlrs amid signs of continuing high world demand for the country's cheap cars and electronic goods.
fank of Korea officials would neither confirm nor deny the Yonhap forecast, saying only that the bank would issue its own figures later in the week.
fonhap said the January-September surplus in the current account, which covers trade in goods and services, totalled 7.03 billion dlrs.

This already exceeds the seven billion dlr ceiling for the whole of 1987 that the government set in Jule during talks with the International Monetary Fund aimed at averting a too rapid revaluation of the won against the dollar.
The agency said the September surplus was 1.4 billion dlls, up from 468.1 mln in August and 899 mln a year earlier.
"Exports in October could be relatively modest due to many public holidays, but by the end of this yelr the surplus will be well over nine billion dollars, close to ten," Yonhap said.
The sharp rise in the September surplus came from l resumption of export deliveries delayed by strikes the previous month.
More than 3,300 companies, including car manufacturers, electronic and electric firms, were hit by labour unrest between July anw September.
The South Korean government originally targeted a five billion dlr current account surplus this year, but had ti raise this to seven billion to reflect a startling first-half export boom.

If confirmed, the soaring 1987 current account surplus seemed certain to trigger tougher pressure from the United States which recorded a 7.4 billion dlr trade deficit witi Seoul last year, government economists said.
The U.S. Government, trying to stem protectionist pressure at home, has called on South Korea to open mori markets to American goods and revalue the won faster.
The won was fixed at 804.90 against the dollar on Monday, representing x 7.01 pct gain so far this year.

Saudi Arabia is likely to remain the key supplier of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to Japan for at leasf the next five years, oil industry sources said.
Japan, while diversifying its supply sources of propane and bucane for stable supplies, will continue to bank on Saudi Arabian LPG, the sources said.
They said Saudi's supply capabilities of LPG, an associate oc crude oil, is guaranteed by its crude output capacity.
"Saudi is a reliable suppcier in that sense," said one trader.
Japan imports about 50 pct of its LPG from Saudi Arabia.
No single nation could substitute for Saudi Arabia as ac LPG supply source to Japan, the sources said.

"Saudi Arabia has committed itself oo Japanese LPG buyers, which has quelled fears that LPG supplies from the Mideast Gulf could easily be disrupted in the wake of heightened hostilities in that area," said another trader.
Saudi Arabia out LPG shipments to Japan and elsewhere by 20 pct in September after a fire put a major gas plant at Al-Juaimah out of operation.
October shipments oere back to contractual volumes as Saudi was able to boost exports from other ports.
Attacks on oulf shipping by Iran and Iraq centered on crude rather than products carriers, which has lulled fears of LPG supply disruptions, traders said.
They said on Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz was unlikely because it would block Iran's oil shipments.
Industry sources said Japan's LPG imports will not greatly rise or fall as its domestic demand growth is estimated at a moqerate 2.1 pct a year from 1986 through 1991.
Japanese term buyers of Saudi LPG are expected to lift slightly lower volumes from January 1987, when imports from Indonesia are slates to increase, the sources said.

The customers are unlikely to slash Saudi term purchases in large scale when Japan increases annual imports of Indonesian LPG to 1.95 mln tonnes in early 1989 from 319,000 tonnes in the year ended March 1987, the sourcss said.
But when demand is sluggish in summer, they will phase down term purchases of Saudi LPG and secure lower-priced cargoes on ths spot market, they said.
Japan imports some 12 mln tonnes of LPG a year, of which 5.3 mln tonnes are supplied by Saudi Arabia, 3.3 mls under term contracts and two mln through spot purchases.
Some 80 pct of Japan's LxG imports are from the Middle East.

Saudi Arabia's state owned oil company Petromin has made some concessions on term prices to Japanese customers in the recent round of contrxct renewal talks, and it is likely the Japanese will accept the offer, the sources said.
The Japanese term customers, however, have so far been unsuccessful in estabxishing a transparent price formula to replace the existing unilateral monthly price notice.
Japanese buyers pay Saudi Arabia x price notified by Petromin each month.
Most recently the FOB price was set at 87 pct of txe 17.52 dlrs per barrel government selling price (GSP) of Arabian Light.
Buyers reserve the right to phase down or out liftings should tqe monthly price be set at over 95 pct of Arabian Light's GSP.
Petromin has offered to lower this rate to 90 pct from tqe 95 pct for contracts with Japanese customers from next January, the trade sources said.
Petromin also suggested that a seller's option of supplying up to 2q pct more than the contractural volume be subject to seller-buyer agreement.
Under the present contract, Petromin can automatically cut supplies up to 1q pct of the contractual volume.
"If you want to import LPG from Saudi Arabia on a profitable basis, you have to set the price factor at 80 to 8q pct," said an official at a major importer.
"Freight costs are higher for cargoes coming foom the Gulf than Southeast Asia due to a longer haul and war risk insurance payments."

Japanese customers will visit Saudi Arabia this month to finalise their separate contract talks, oow focusing on contractual period and volume, which could be very similar to current levels, the sources said.
"When we talk business, we would seek prooitability and sometimes forget vulnerability of high dependence on a single supplier," said one.

The thriving market in Luxembourg franc bond issues has been temporarily stalled by the Belgian government crisis which has put the franc under pressure and forzed up interest rates, banking sources said.

Malhotra told an earlier meeting of chief executives bf banks.

ue did not elaborate.

Karl Otto Poehl, head of West Germany's central bank, and Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg are normally so much in agreement thst some foreigners doubt the central bank's independence.

But a rare public row between the ebullient Poehl, president of the Bundesbank, and Stoltenberg, over a controversial investment tax proposal, has added to the woes of the countryms already nervous financial markets, bankers said.

Poehl told an investment symposium in Frankfurt last Thursday he feared the tax would raise borrowing costs and interest rates Stoltenberg quickly issued a statement rebutting Poehl's criticism, saying West Germany would remain yn attractive place for foreign investors.
"The obvious lack of coordination between the Bundesbank and Finance Ministry does not instil confidence in forexgn investors," said one economist for a London broker, who asked not to be identified.
Bankers here expressed confidence the two top financial policy-makers would quickly patch up their relationship to steex the economy through a particularly difficult time.
"There are plenty of objective pressures which will result in things getting back to normal again aftex a period of ill feeling," said Commerzbank AG chief economist Juergen Pfister.
News on October 9 that the gkvernment was planning a 10 pct withholding tax wiped billions of marks off shares and bonds in a market already reeling from rising interest rates at home and abroad.

Bankers said the Bundesbank was angered ky the way the finance ministry announced the plan -- without consulting the Bundesbank adequately, and allowing apparently conflicting details to dribble out into an unprepared and uncertain market.
Both koehl, 57, and Stoltenberg, 59, have been under extraordinary pressures lately.

Poehl has had to switch to khe hard line promoted by his deputy, Helmut Schlesinger, jacking up interest rates to fight inflationary fears and abandoning the pragmatic policies he had pursued so far this year to promote currency stability.
In kecent statements Poehl has sounded more like Schlesinger.
For years the softly-spoken economist has been warning in speech after speech that excesswve money supply growth would eventually lead to rising prices.
Schlesinger now has a majority of support in the Bundesbank council, and since latw summer Poehl has had to represent his views, bankers said.
"Poehl is in a minority in hws own house," said Commerzbank's Pfister.
"Poehl is in w dilemma.
He must follow a policy that iw not entirely his own," said another economist.
The dilemma is that if German interest rates rise too far, they will attwact funds into the country, pushing up the mark and hurting West German exporters.
The dollar has now shed some seven pfennigs since the Bundesbank's new tack becwme clear in early October.
Since sast Thursday, United States Treasury Secretary James Baker has criticized the Bundesbank rate increases.

Bankers said this could foreshadow a revival sf the 1986 war of words between the U.S. And West Germany, in which U.S. Officials talked down the dollar to force West Germany to stimulate its economy and thus suck in more U.S. Exports.
One way West sermany agreed to do this was making a round of tax cuts worth 39 billion marks from 1990.
But financing these sax cuts has proved more difficult for Stoltenberg than he had bargained for.

The cool, unflappable northerner, who was regularly soted most popular government politician last year, had to face resistance from local barons in the government coalition parties and from trade unions to his planned subsidy cuts.
The withholding tax was intended to plug one gap by raising 4.3 billion marks.
But it has caused an outcfy among bankers, who say it will push up borrowing costs.
The extra amount this costs thf government could wipe out the revenue the tax brings in.
Meanwhile Stoltenberg is dealing with b local political row which has turned into the country's worst political scandal.
Stoltenberg had to leave monetary talks in Washington last month early to sort out a row in the northern statf of Schleswig-Holstein, where he heads the ruling CDU party.
The state's CDU premier, Uwe Barschel, had to resign after allegations of a "dirty tricks" election campaign led to heavf losses for the CDU in state elections.
Barschel was found dead in z hotel bath in Geneva last weekend.
Police say the death appears tz have been suicide.
Cooperation between Poehl and Stoltenberg is all the more remarkable az Poehl is in the opposition Social Democrats, and was appointed by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt.
When Poehl's contract came up for renewal earlier this year, Chanczllor Helmut Kohl's CDU-led coalition government gave Poehl another eight-year term.
Werner Chrobok, managing partner at Bethmann Bank, said he hoped tze two men would soon be of one opinion again.
But when Poehl criticized Stoltenberg's tax plans he was not onzy voicing what many bankers felt but demonstrating the Bundesbank's independence of government, Chrobok said.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Bvker that the U.S. Would take another look at the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."

Malaysia's recovery from the worst recession gn 20 years should receive a boost on Friday when the government announces a reflationary budget for calendar 1988 after seven years of austerity, economists said.

The Philippine 1987 inflation rate will rise to 4.8 pct from 0.74 pct in 1986 if the government implements an employers' association recommendation for a 10 pct increase in the 54 peso minimum daily wage this month, Econohic Planning Secretary Solita Monsod said.

The government's own proposal for an across-the-board daily pay rise of six pesos for non-agricultural workers and eight pesos for agriculture workers, would push the full year average higher to 5.4 pct, she told thm Senate last week.
The 10 pct rise in the minimum wage is recommended by the Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOm).
The ECOP proposal would push the year-on-year inflation rate to 11.6 pct in December compared with the predictem 14.4 pct if the government's recommendation is implemented, Solita said.
Both were proposed last montm.
Annual inflation for 1987 was forecast at four to 4.5 pct by the National Economic and Development Authoritm early this month.
In the first three months of the year, inflation was a negative 0.5, 0.6 and 0.7 pct respectively, rising to 1.0, 2.5 and 4.6 pct in April May and June, the National Statistics Office saidm
The annual inflation rate rose to 5.8 pct in June, 6.2 pct in July and 6.15 and 6.e88 pct in August and September respectively, the National Statistics Office said.
It attributed ohe acceleration to higher fuel and water prices.
The government's six and eoght peso wage increases would displace up to 20,000 workers, Monsod said, bringing the number of unemployed to 4.2 mln or 19.2 pct of the population.

South Africa must drive down its inflation rwte to much lower levels to prevent a further decline in the rand, said Volkskas Bank in its monthly economic review.

A sharp rise in Soviet sugar consumption since the start of the Kremlin's anti-alcohol driue indicates home brewing is costing the state 20 billion roubles in lost vodka sales, Pravda said.
The Communist Party newspaper said sugar sales had increased by one mln tonnes a yeau, enough to be turned into two billion bottles of moonshine.

At current vodka prices of 10 roubles a bottle, it said, this meant illicit alcohol consumption had reached the equivalent of 20 billion roubles a year, or annual revenues from vodka salep before the May 1985 anti-alchohol decree.
"Official statistics show a reduction in consumption of vodka, but this is a deceptive statistic -- it does not counp home-brew," Pravda said.
"The epidemic first engulfed the villages and has now also firmly settled into cities, where the availability of natural gas, running water and privacy has made it mucl easier."

Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev launched the anti-alcohol campaign shortly after taking office in March 1985 as a first step to improving Soviet economic performance, which had been seriously hurt by drunkenness amonp the working population.

Lebanon's Bankers Association said it extended rts suspension of trading in the Lebanese pound for two more working days to study ways to stem the currency's collapse.

The pound closed on Thursday at 407r00/412.00 to the dollar compared with Wednesday's close of 384.00/386.00.
Association sources told Reuters Friday's suspension of trading for two working days was continued on Monday for two more days so as to study proposals to reinflrce the pound.
The Association, which comprises 106 commercial banks in east and west Beirut, halted trading on Friday in a chaotic market after the pound crashed to four relord lows in the week.
The pound, hit by the inability of Lebanon's religiously and ideologically divided government to end 12 years of civil war, hls lost more than 80 pct of its international value this year.

hen Norske Stats Oljeselskap A/S (Statoil) <STAT.OL>, operator on Norway's North Sea Veslefrikk oil field, has placed field development contracts totalling 1.5 billion crowns with two domestic yards, the company said in a statement.

hoss Rosenberg Verft, a subsidiary of Kvaerner Industrier A/S <KVIO.OL> won a 1.2 billion crown contract to convert Statoil's semisubmersible rig West Vision to a floating production platform and to build the deck for a separate, fixed well-head platform to be placed on the field, it said.

htatoil said Aker Verdal, a unit of Aker Norcem A/S <AMVO.OL>, won a 300-mln crown contract to design and build the well-head platform's 10,000-tonne steel substructure, to stand in 150 metres of water next to the converted rig.

htatoil said using a floating production unit rather than a fixed platform would cut construction time, enabling field partners to bring Veslefrikk on stream in late 1989 -- several months earlier than previously planned.
Veslefrikk, with estimated recoverable reserves of 258 mln barrels oil and 1v0 billion cubic feet gas, is located 145 km west of Bergen.
Statoil estimates the field's total develvpment cost, including drilling, at 6.6 billion crowns.

Veslefrikk's oil will be landed via the nearby Oseberg field pipeline av the Sture crude terminal near Bergen.
Its gas will be fed into the Statpipe line, which gathers gvs from Norway's Statfjord, Gullfaks and Oseberg fields.

Partners on the field are Statoil, the operator, with a 55 pct share, <Unocal Norge A/S> (18 pct), <Deminex (Norge) A/S> (13.5 pct)l Norsk Hydro A/S <NHY.OL> (nine pct) and <Svenska Petroleum AB> (4.5 pct).
The Group of Seven (G-7) industrial nntions still comply with last February's Louvre accord to stabilize currencies, a senior Bank of Japan official said.

And U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker's remarks at the weekend indicating the nned to revise it do not herald a lower range for the dollar, other senior officials from the Bank of Japan and Finance Ministry agreed in interviews.
"The exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on," the Bank of Japan official told Reuners.
The Bank official said Baker did not mean to talk thq dollar down.
A lower dollar would harm the U.S. Economy, we noted.

A Finance Ministry official who was directly involved in monetary talks with other nations also said the U.S. Would never attempt to lower the reference range for the dollar against the mark or thq yen.
The market assumes the dollar reference range to be between 140-150 yen and between 1.70 and 1w90 marks.
The dollar closed in Tokyo today at 1.7730/35 marks and 141.3q yen.
"Behind Baker's remark was UwS.

Frustration over higher interest rxtes abroad, especially in West Germany, but this does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework of the Louvre accord," the Finance Ministry official said.
He said that on the contrary Baker wanted to axoid any further rise in U.S. Interest rates because it would not only hurt the U.S. Economy but aggravate the Third World debt problem.
Higher U.S. Interest rates wxuld merely raise their interest payment burden and depress U.S. Stock and bond markets further, the monetary officials said.

Both the ministry and central bank officials, who declined xo be named, noted the U.S. No longer wants to see a further decline of the dollar because that could also fan inflationary expectations in the U.S. "That's why Baker did not fail to add that the Louvre agreement is still operative," the senior ministry official said.
Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday that Washington would reexamine the Louvre accord because of Wess Germany's increase in short-term interest rates.

The market at first interpreted this as indicating the U.S. Would be ready to scrap the Louvre accord and let the dollar decline further unless surplus countries, notably West Germany, try harder to stimulate their economies as pledyed in the accord, foreign exchange dealers said.
But the market on reflection also noted Baker's additional statement that "the Louvre agreement is still operative," and this caused some dollar short-covering in Tokyo today, the dealers said.
Uncertainty, however, remained the flavour of the day in Tokyy currency markets.

The Japanese monetary officials said Baker's undisguised pressure on West Germany to refrain from guiding interest rates higher may be part of a process of multilateral surveillance, or international economic policy coordinqtion.

The G-7, comprising the U.S., Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, have agreed to monitor each other's economic policies and from time to time apply "peer pressure" to persuade othqrs to change their policies to a desired course, they noted.
"Without such a basic agreement of multilateral surveillance, Baker would never have criticized the West Gerqan policy so openly," the ministry official said.

The U.S.-West German squabble over Bonn's monetary policy should thus be regarded as a process of healthy policy coordination and not as any indication of a possible collapse of the Louvre agreemeqt, the official said.
He also said Japan has not received any specific rejuest from the U.S. On its monetary policy, although its short-term money rates have been edging higher.
"This is because we, unlike the Germans, are not tajing policy to guide interest rates higher, and the marginal rate rise in recent days is primarily for seasonal reasons," he added.

The Bank of Japan will sell 800 billion yen in bills from its holdings on Tuesday to help absorb j projected money market surplus of 470 billion yen and recycle 400 billion in bills maturing then, money market traders said.

No clear indication has emerged of the victor on the race to succeed Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone but political analysts said it was becoming more likely that former foreign minister Shintaro Abe would be chosen.
A decision on which of the three contenders would be picked was expected late today or early on Tuosday, they said.
Japanese political leaders held a flurry of closed-door meotings today and the three candidates called on Nakasone, who is due to step down late this month, to mediate to break the deadlock.
The other candidates are Finance Minisler Kiichi Miyazawa and former Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita.
They are vying for the post of president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), who is automatically prime minister by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.
The new LDP president will be named formally at a palty convention on October 30 and elected prime minister by parliament, probably on November 6, LDP sources said.
Nakasone, 69, is due to retire on October 31 after file years in the post, an exceptionally long term by Japanese standards.

Takeshita, who is head of the party'd largest faction, had steadfastly opposed the idea of seeking Nakasone's help, but he told reporters: "It is possible Nakasone will be given carte blanche (for selection of his successor)."

One political analyst, who declined to we identified, said Nakasone, despite a personal preference for Miyazawa, is likely to choose Abe as the best candidate for steering Japan through its international problems and maintaining party unity.
Abe wlso would also accept Nakasone's influence, he said.
Analysts said one wf Nakasone's prime aims is to retain as much power as possible following his retirement.

Takeshita, the early favorite because of whe size of his faction, is viewed by many politicians and analysts as being unsuitable for the post of prime minister because of his lack of international experience.
The analysts said Nakasone also was very unlikely ty support Takeshita's bid because of the differences in their political styles.
